Description: A simple technique to calm the nervous system by controlling your breath.
Instructions:
1. Inhale for 4s.
2. Hold for 4s.
3. Exhale for 4s.
4. Hold for 4s. Repeat 5-10 times.

Description: Engages all five senses to bring your focus back to the present moment.
Instructions: Name 5 things you see, 4 things you feel, 3 things you hear, 2 things you smell, 1 thing you taste.

Description: A technique to overcome procrastination by committing to just five minutes of a task.
Instructions: Set a timer for 5 minutes and start the task. You can stop when it rings, but you'll often keep going.

Description: Breaking a large, overwhelming project down into small, manageable steps.
Instructions: List all the steps for your project. Focus on completing only the first, smallest step.

Description: A non-confrontational way to express your feelings during a conflict.
Instructions: Structure your sentence as: "I feel [emotion] when [behavior] because [reason]."

Description: Engaging in a small, positive, or rewarding activity to counter low mood and inertia.
Instructions: Choose one small activity you usually enjoy (e.g., listen to a song, walk outside) and do it.

Description: Writing down all thoughts, tasks, and worries to clear your mind.
Instructions: Take a piece of paper and write down everything on your mind for 10 minutes without judgment.

Description: A technique to reduce tension by tensing and then relaxing different muscle groups in the body.
Instructions: Systematically tense one muscle group (e.g., fists) for 5s, then completely relax for 10s. Move to the next group.

Description: Focusing completely on sounds around you or on a specific piece of music to enhance present moment awareness.
Instructions: Close your eyes and pay attention to all sounds, without judgment. Alternatively, listen to a song and notice every instrument and nuance.

Description: A time management method that uses a timer to break down work into focused intervals, traditionally 25 minutes in length, separated by short breaks.
Instructions: 1. Set a timer for 25 min and work on a single task. 2. When the timer rings, take a 5 min break. 3. After 4 "pomodoros," take a longer 15-30 min break.

Description: Regularly writing down things you are grateful for to foster a positive outlook.
Instructions: Write down 3-5 things you are genuinely grateful for each day. Be specific about why.

Description: Creating mental images to rehearse desired outcomes or calm the mind.
Instructions: Close your eyes and vividly imagine a peaceful scene, or successfully completing a challenging task, focusing on all sensory details.

Description: Using cold or heat to quickly shift physiological states and interrupt intense emotions.
Instructions: Splash cold water on your face, hold an ice pack, or drink a warm beverage slowly.

Description: Positive statements repeated to challenge negative thoughts and promote self-belief.
Instructions: Choose a positive statement (e.g., "I am capable and strong") and repeat it to yourself daily, especially when facing challenges.

Description: Designating a specific, limited time each day to address worries, rather than letting them intrude throughout the day.
Instructions: Choose a 15-minute slot each day. If a worry arises outside this time, make a note and defer it to your "worry time."

Description: Assembling a collection of items that engage your senses in a comforting way to help regulate intense emotions.
Instructions: Prepare a small kit with items like a scented oil, a smooth stone, a soft fabric, or a comforting photo. Use when feeling overwhelmed.

Description: A practice of bringing awareness to different parts of the body to notice sensations and release tension.
Instructions: Lie down and systematically bring your attention to each part of your body, noticing any sensations without judgment.

Description: Similar to box breathing, this technique involves inhaling, holding, exhaling, and holding for equal counts to regulate the nervous system.
Instructions: 1. Inhale slowly for 4 counts. 2. Hold your breath for 4 counts. 3. Exhale slowly for 4 counts. 4. Hold your breath for 4 counts. Repeat several cycles.

Description: Identifying and evaluating unhelpful or irrational thoughts by looking for evidence for and against them.
Instructions: When you have a negative thought, ask: "What's the evidence for this thought? What's the evidence against it? Is there another way to look at this?"

Description: Creating a strong association between a specific physical touch or gesture and a positive emotional state.
Instructions: Recall a strong positive memory. As you feel the emotion, squeeze your thumb and forefinger together. Repeat several times. Later, use the squeeze to evoke the feeling.

Description: A mindfulness-based strategy for riding out intense urges or emotions without acting on them.
Instructions: When an urge arises, notice it like a wave – observe its beginning, peak, and eventual decrease, without judgment or action.

Description: Attaching a new desired habit to an existing, established habit to make it easier to remember and perform.
Instructions: Identify an existing daily habit (e.g., brushing teeth). After it, immediately perform your new desired habit (e.g., 2 minutes of stretching).

Description: Scheduling specific blocks of time for certain tasks or activities in your calendar.
Instructions: Allocate specific time slots in your daily or weekly calendar for focused work, breaks, exercise, or other important activities.

Description: Focusing on one task at a time, rather than multitasking, to improve concentration and reduce errors.
Instructions: Close all unnecessary tabs and distractions. Dedicate your full attention to one task until it's complete or you take a planned break.

Description: Writing about positive experiences, personal strengths, and successes to reinforce self-efficacy and positive beliefs.
Instructions: Write about a recent success, a personal strength you utilized, or a positive experience, focusing on the details and your feelings.

Description: A quick practice to offer yourself kindness and understanding during moments of difficulty or suffering.
Instructions: 1. Notice suffering: "This is a moment of suffering." 2. Common humanity: "Suffering is a part of life." 3. Self-kindness: Place hand on heart, "May I be kind to myself."

Description: Writing freely about thoughts and feelings related to a stressful or emotional event to process and gain perspective.
Instructions: Write continuously for 15-20 minutes about a challenging experience or your deepest thoughts and feelings without worrying about grammar or coherence.

Description: A DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy) skill to create a pause before reacting impulsively to intense emotions.
Instructions: Stop what you're doing. Take a step back. Observe your thoughts, feelings, and sensations. Proceed mindfully.

Description: Paying full attention to the experience of eating, including the taste, texture, and smell of food.
Instructions: Eat slowly, savoring each bite. Notice the colors, aromas, and textures. Pay attention to your body's hunger and fullness cues.

Description: Fully concentrating on what is being said rather than just passively hearing the message.
Instructions: Give the speaker your full attention, make eye contact, nod occasionally, and summarize what you heard to confirm understanding.

Description: Changing the way you look at a situation, thought, or belief to find a more positive or constructive interpretation.
Instructions: When faced with a negative situation, try to find an alternative, more positive or neutral way of viewing it.

Description: Standing in front of a mirror and saying positive affirmations to yourself to build self-love and confidence.
Instructions: Look into your eyes in a mirror and say empowering affirmations such as, "I love and accept myself," or "I am worthy."

Description: Spending time in natural environments to reduce stress and improve well-being.
Instructions: Go for a walk in a park, sit by a lake, or simply observe nature from a window. Focus on the sights, sounds, and smells.

Description: Identifying and prioritizing your core values to guide your choices and actions.
Instructions: List your top 3-5 core values (e.g., honesty, creativity, family). Use them as a compass when making important decisions.

Description: Quickly tidying a small area to reduce mental clutter and increase a sense of control.
Instructions: Set a timer for 10 minutes and quickly tidy up one small area – your desk, a drawer, or a corner of a room.

Description: Replacing negative internal dialogue with encouraging and supportive thoughts.
Instructions: Become aware of your inner critic. When you notice negative self-talk, consciously replace it with a positive, realistic alternative.

Description: Performing light, easy stretches to release physical tension and improve flexibility.
Instructions: Do a few gentle stretches for your neck, shoulders, or back. Hold each stretch for 20-30 seconds, breathing deeply.

Description: Reinterpreting a stressful situation or thought from a place of kindness and understanding towards oneself.
Instructions: Instead of self-criticism, imagine how a compassionate friend would view your situation or thoughts. Offer yourself the same kindness.

Description: Deliberately sitting or lying down and doing absolutely nothing for a short period, just being present.
Instructions: Find a quiet spot, set a timer, and simply sit or lie without engaging in any activity, thoughts, or distractions.

Description: Clearly defining your limits and communicating them respectfully to others to protect your time, energy, and well-being.
Instructions: Identify your personal limits. Practice saying "no" politely when something oversteps your boundaries, or clearly state what you need.

Description: Regularly noting your mood to identify patterns, triggers, and the effectiveness of coping strategies.
Instructions: Use a journal or an app to record your mood at different times of the day, along with any significant events or feelings.

Description: Writing freely to explore thoughts, feelings, and experiences, leading to self-discovery and problem-solving.
Instructions: Dedicate time to write about a specific problem, a recurring feeling, or a challenging situation to gain clarity and new perspectives.

Description: Placing visual reminders in your environment to prompt desired behaviors or habits.
Instructions: Leave your running shoes by the door, put your vitamins next to your toothbrush, or place a sticky note with a reminder on your monitor.

Description: Performing any task that takes less than one minute immediately, to prevent procrastination and build momentum.
Instructions: If a task can be done in under 60 seconds (e.g., put away a dish, reply to a quick email), do it right away.

Description: Modifying your environment's sensory input to create a more calming or stimulating atmosphere.
Instructions: Dim lights, play calming music, or use earplugs to reduce overstimulation. Alternatively, open a window or play energizing music.

Description: Learning and practicing new skills to increase competence and confidence in handling challenges.
Instructions: Identify a small, achievable skill you want to learn (e.g., basic coding, a new recipe) and dedicate regular time to practice it.

Description: Asking yourself open-ended questions to encourage deeper thinking and self-awareness.
Instructions: At the end of the day, ask yourself: "What went well today? What was challenging? What did I learn? What could I do differently tomorrow?"

Description: A quick grounding exercise using an acronym to mindfully observe and accept difficult thoughts and feelings.
Instructions: Recognize the feeling. Allow it to be there. Investigate with kindness. Non-identification (don't get lost in it).

Description: Creating distance from your thoughts, viewing them as mental events rather than absolute truths.
Instructions: Observe thoughts as if they are clouds passing by or words on a screen. Say "I'm having the thought that..." before a negative thought.

Description: Asking "why?" repeatedly to get to the root cause of a problem or feeling.
Instructions: Start with a problem, then ask "Why is this happening?" for each answer until you uncover the core issue.

Description: Using verbal cues to help you visualize a calming place or scenario to reduce stress.
Instructions: Listen to a guided meditation or a recording that describes a peaceful scene, engaging all your senses in the visualization.

Description: Incorporating short bursts of physical activity throughout the day to re-energize and reduce sedentary time.
Instructions: Every hour, stand up, stretch, walk a few steps, or do a few jumping jacks for 1-2 minutes.

Description: A structured approach to identifying, analyzing, and resolving problems systematically.
Instructions: 1. Define the problem. 2. Brainstorm solutions. 3. Evaluate options. 4. Choose the best. 5. Implement. 6. Review.

Description: Paying attention to the physical sensations of walking and the environment around you.
Instructions: As you walk, notice the feeling of your feet on the ground, the movement of your legs, and the sights and sounds around you.

Description: Deliberately thinking through your worst fear to diminish its power and create coping plans.
Instructions: Identify your biggest fear related to a situation. Play out the worst possible outcome, then brainstorm how you would cope if it happened.

Description: Assessing how different activities impact your energy levels throughout the day.
Instructions: Over a day or week, note down activities and how energized or drained you feel afterward to understand your energy patterns.

Description: Taking a planned break from digital devices and social media to reduce overstimulation and improve focus.
Instructions: Set specific times or days where you completely disconnect from non-essential digital devices and engage in other activities.

Description: Acknowledging and allowing difficult emotions or situations to exist without resistance or judgment.
Instructions: Instead of fighting a difficult feeling, acknowledge its presence without trying to change it immediately. "I notice I'm feeling angry right now."

Description: Focusing on completing only the top three most important tasks for the day.
Instructions: At the start of your day, identify the 3 most crucial tasks you need to accomplish and prioritize them above all else.

Description: Deep, diaphragmatic breathing that engages the diaphragm, promoting relaxation and reducing stress.
Instructions: Place one hand on your chest and one on your belly. Inhale deeply through your nose, feeling your belly rise. Exhale slowly through your mouth.

Description: Clearly and assertively communicating your wants, needs, and boundaries to others.
Instructions: Use "I" statements to articulate what you need or want in a situation without blaming or demanding.

Description: Detaching from intense cravings or impulses by observing them rather than acting on them.
Instructions: When an urge arises, label it as "an urge" and notice the physical sensations, without engaging in the desired behavior.

Description: Engaging in activities that align with your core values, even when motivation is low.
Instructions: Identify a value (e.g., connection). Choose a small action that reflects it (e.g., call a friend), and do it, regardless of how you feel.

Description: A quick decision-making process for managing your to-do list efficiently.
Instructions: For each task: Can it be Deleted? Can it be Delegated? If not, Do it now or schedule it.

Description: A framework for setting clear and achievable goals.
Instructions: Ensure your goals are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound.

Description: A technique for identifying and replacing unwanted repetitive behaviors with a competing response.
Instructions: Identify the specific behavior and its triggers. Choose a less noticeable, non-harmful competing behavior to perform instead.

Description: A discreet signal to a trusted person when you need support or a break in a social situation.
Instructions: Agree with a friend or family member on a subtle hand signal (e.g., touching your ear) that means "I need a moment" or "Please help me disengage."

Description: Working or performing tasks alongside another person (virtually or in-person) to increase focus and motivation, even if they're doing something different.
Instructions: Find a friend, colleague, or an online "body doubling" stream/app. Simply exist in the same space (physical or virtual) while you both work on separate tasks.

Description: Curating a personal collection of items that provide comforting or regulating sensory input (tactile, visual, auditory, olfactory).
Instructions: Gather items like fidget toys, textured fabrics, smooth stones, noise-canceling headphones, a favorite scent, or a small visual stim toy. Use them when feeling overwhelmed or understimulated.

Description: Deliberately directing periods of intense, concentrated focus towards desired tasks, rather than fighting or being derailed by them.
Instructions: When you feel hyperfocus "kicking in," quickly direct it towards a task you need to complete. Remove all other distractions to maximize the period of intense concentration.

Description: Mentally or physically planning out all the tiny, often overlooked steps of a task before starting, to avoid getting stuck or overwhelmed.
Instructions: Before a complex task (e.g., cooking a meal, going out), mentally walk through every single micro-step and identify potential sticking points or forgotten items. Write them down if helpful.

Description: Using highly visual, often simplified, checklists for routines or tasks to externalize memory and reduce mental load.
Instructions: Create short, clear, visual checklists (written, drawn, or digital) for daily routines (e.g., morning routine, leaving the house, going to bed). Check off each step as you go.

Description: Firmly but politely declining commitments or social interactions when mental/emotional capacity is low, without over-explaining.
Instructions: When feeling drained or overstimulated, practice saying a simple, clear "No, thank you, I won't be able to make it today," without feeling obligated to provide extensive reasons.

Description: Grouping similar types of tasks or tasks requiring similar energy levels together, rather than mixing them throughout the day.
Instructions: Categorize your to-do list by energy demand (e.g., "low effort admin," "high focus creative," "physical tasks") and tackle them in blocks according to your fluctuating energy.

Description: Deliberately designing different areas of your home or workspace to cater to specific sensory needs (e.g., quiet zone, stim zone, bright zone).
Instructions: Designate a quiet corner with soft lighting and comfortable seating, a brighter area for focused work, or a space where you can safely engage in repetitive movements without disturbing others.

Description: Understanding that social interactions might require selecting a specific "social script" or "tool" rather than relying on intuitive flow.
Instructions: Before a social interaction, mentally identify what kind of "script" or "tool" might be needed (e.g., active listening, asking specific questions, focusing on a shared interest).

Description: Having a pre-planned set of steps to take when approaching or experiencing sensory overload, emotional dysregulation, or burnout.
Instructions: Identify your personal shutdown/meltdown triggers and early warning signs. Create a step-by-step plan: e.g., go to quiet space, use sensory kit, deep breathing, no demands for X time.

Description: Using a specific, comforting object or routine to help bridge the gap between tasks or environments, reducing transition difficulty.
Instructions: Carry a specific fidget toy, listen to a particular song, or perform a small, consistent ritual (e.g., tap your fingers 3 times) when moving from one activity/place to another.

Description: Expressing a highly specialized interest or topic in detail to a willing listener as a way to regulate and share passion.
Instructions: Find a trusted friend or online community who enjoys or tolerates "info dumping." Ask "Is it okay if I info-dump about X for a few minutes?" and share your passion.

Description: Turning mundane or difficult tasks into a game or challenge to make them more engaging and achievable.
Instructions: Assign points to chores, race against a timer, or create a reward system (e.g., "If I finish this, I get 15 min of special interest time").

Description: Deliberately planning short periods throughout the day to unmask and relax social performance.
Instructions: Identify times or places where you can safely be yourself (e.g., in your car, a private room). Schedule short breaks to drop the mask and recharge.

Description: Having a variety of fidget tools strategically placed in different common locations (desk, bag, car) for immediate access.
Instructions: Keep a different type of fidget (e.g., tangle, smooth stone, ring) in your pocket, on your desk, in your car, and in your bag for easy, immediate access when needed.

Description: Proactively incorporating a variety of sensory inputs throughout the day to maintain optimal regulation, not just in crisis.
Instructions: Plan your day to include both calming (e.g., weighted blanket, quiet time) and stimulating (e.g., movement breaks, bright colors) sensory activities.

Description: Using the "Spoon Theory" to realistically assess daily energy levels and set achievable limits without guilt.
Instructions: At the start of the day, assess how many "spoons" (units of energy) you have. Allocate them to tasks, understanding that certain activities cost more spoons and you have a finite supply.

Description: Relying on specific comfortable clothing items that provide consistent, non-distracting sensory input.
Instructions: Identify clothing items (e.g., a specific soft shirt, comfortable socks, a loose pair of pants) that feel consistently "right" and wear them often to reduce sensory overwhelm.

Description: Using visual cues like sticky notes or colored calendar blocks to represent dedicated time for specific tasks.
Instructions: Use a physical planner with colored markers or a digital calendar to visually block out time for tasks. Seeing the blocks helps with transitions and focus.

Description: Engaging in separate, individual activities alongside another person, providing social connection without direct interaction pressure.
Instructions: Suggest doing individual activities (e.g., reading, crafting, working on laptops) in the same room as a friend or partner, enjoying their presence without needing constant conversation.

Description: Using specific background sounds (e.g., brown noise, certain music) to create a consistent auditory environment and reduce sensory overwhelm.
Instructions: Play brown noise, lo-fi music, or instrumental tracks while working or relaxing to block out distracting or unpredictable environmental sounds.
Unnamed: 5: https://www.abtaba.com/blog/noise-sensitivity-in-autism

Description: Connecting disliked chores or tasks to a special interest or hyperfocus to make them more tolerable.
Instructions: If you love history, listen to a history podcast while doing dishes. If you love organizing, categorize items by obscure historical periods.
Unnamed: 5: motivation, productivity, executive function, ADHD, hyperfocus, special interest

Description: Designating a specific, personalized space in your home solely for sensory regulation and decompression.
Instructions: Set up a "recharge zone" with specific comfort items: a weighted blanket, noise-canceling headphones, dim lighting, soft textures, and preferred stim tools.
Unnamed: 5: emotional regulation, sensory integration, self-soothing, calm space, neurodiversity, sensory overload

Description: Relying heavily on external tools (apps, notebooks, voice memos) to offload memory and planning tasks.
Instructions: Use a dedicated notes app, a small notebook, or voice memos to immediately record thoughts, ideas, tasks, and appointments as they arise.
Unnamed: 5: executive function, memory, planning, cognitive load, productivity, ADHD, working memory

Description: Identifying one or two absolutely non-negotiable fixed points in your day to help structure other, more flexible routines.
Instructions: Choose one or two things you always do at the same time (e.g., take medication, morning coffee, walk the dog) and build other routines around these anchors.
Unnamed: 5: routine management, habit formation, executive function, predictability, daily structure

Description: Using specific foods or drinks for their sensory properties (texture, temperature, taste) to provide comfort and regulation.
Instructions: Keep favorite comfort foods or drinks on hand that provide specific sensory input you enjoy (e.g., crunchy snacks, warm beverages, smooth textures).
Unnamed: 5: self-soothing, sensory regulation, emotional regulation, comfort, neurodiversity, emotional eating

Description: Actively giving oneself permission to complete tasks "good enough" rather than striving for unattainable perfection.
Instructions: When starting a task, tell yourself, "It doesn't have to be perfect, it just needs to be done." Focus on completion over flawless execution.
Unnamed: 5: self-compassion, perfectionism, productivity, anxiety, burnout, executive function, ADHD

Description: Favoring short, concise social interactions over prolonged or open-ended conversations.
Instructions: In social settings, aim for brief, direct exchanges. Ask specific questions, provide concise answers, and excuse yourself gracefully when social energy depletes.
Unnamed: 5: social communication, energy management, social fatigue, neurodiversity, boundaries, communication strategies

Description: Regularly pausing to scan your body and environment for sensory input that might be causing distress or comfort.
Instructions: Periodically throughout the day, pause and ask: "What do I hear, see, feel, smell, taste right now? Is anything bothering me? What feels good?"
Unnamed: 5: mindfulness, sensory awareness, self-regulation, distress, grounding, interoception, autism

Description: Rewarding task completion with dedicated time for special interests, hobbies, or deep dives into preferred topics.
Instructions: After completing a challenging task, allow yourself a pre-determined amount of time to engage fully in your favorite special interest or hobby, guilt-free.
Unnamed: 5: motivation, productivity, rewards, special interest, hyperfocus, behavioral reinforcement, ADHD, autism

Description: Keeping digital tabs or physical items open as visual reminders of unfinished tasks or thoughts, acting as an external working memory.
Instructions: Instead of closing browser tabs or putting physical items away immediately, leave them "open" or visible as a prompt for later action or thought processing.

Description: Using headphones (even without music) as a clear, non-verbal signal that you're unavailable for conversation or need a quiet space.
Instructions: Wear headphones in public, shared living spaces, or even at your desk to subtly communicate "do not disturb" or "I need to focus/regulate."
Unnamed: 5: social communication, boundaries, non-verbal cues, sensory management, focus, privacy, autism, sensory overload

Description: Doing household chores or tasks simultaneously with a partner or housemate, even if doing separate tasks, for shared motivation.
Instructions: Coordinate with a housemate to do separate chores at the same time (e.g., one cleans the kitchen, the other does laundry) to create a shared productive atmosphere.
Unnamed: 5: productivity, motivation, shared tasks, accountability, social facilitation, parallel play, neurodiversity

Description: Alternating between different types of tasks (e.g., high-focus, low-focus, physical) to maintain engagement and prevent burnout.
Instructions: If you have multiple tasks, rotate between them when focus wanes on one, or intersperse a demanding task with a less demanding one.
Unnamed: 5: productivity, focus, engagement, burnout prevention, task switching, cognitive flexibility

Description: Using weighted items on the lap or body to provide deep pressure input, which can be calming and help with focus.
Instructions: Place a weighted lap pad or small weighted blanket on your lap while working, studying, or resting to experience calming deep pressure.
Unnamed: 5: sensory regulation, deep pressure, calming, focus, anxiety, proprioception, autism, sensory processing

Description: Adapting natural self-stimulatory behaviors into more socially acceptable or less noticeable forms.
Instructions: If you bite your nails, try chewing gum. If you pace, try walking circles while on a call. Find subtle replacements that still provide sensory input.
Unnamed: 5: stimming, self-regulation, sensory input, social adaptation, coping mechanism, discreet, neurodiversity

Description: Quickly jotting down overwhelming thoughts or ideas to clear your mind and externalize mental clutter, without needing to act on them immediately.
Instructions: Keep a dedicated notebook or digital document for "info dumps" where you quickly write down every thought, worry, or idea that comes to mind, then set it aside.
Unnamed: 5: cognitive offloading, mental clutter, overwhelm, anxiety, thought organization, external memory, executive function

Description: Implementing small, immediate, and satisfying rewards for completing even the smallest, most dreaded steps.
Instructions: After sending that email, allow yourself 2 minutes of a favorite silly video, or a square of chocolate, to reinforce the tiny effort.
Unnamed: 5: motivation, behavioral activation, rewards, procrastination, task initiation, habit formation

Description: Creating a personalized sound environment (e.g., specific playlists, nature sounds, white/pink noise) to aid focus or relaxation.
Instructions: Experiment with different types of background sound — rain, forest sounds, instrumental game soundtracks, or specific frequency noises — to find what helps you focus or relax best.
Unnamed: 5: sensory regulation, auditory processing, focus, relaxation, sound environment, concentration, soundscape

Description: Having a specific set of actions to perform when a routine is broken or feels off, to help get back on track.
Instructions: If your morning routine falls apart, have a "reset" sequence (e.g., brush teeth, drink water, put on comfy clothes) to regain a sense of control.
Unnamed: 5: routine management, habit breaking, re-establishing routine, self-regulation, control, predictability

Description: Reducing the number of minor daily decisions to conserve mental energy for more important choices.
Instructions: Pre-plan meals, lay out clothes the night before, or create default choices for common scenarios (e.g., always ordering the same coffee).
Unnamed: 5: decision fatigue, executive function, energy conservation, mental load, productivity, planning, cognitive load

Description: Using physical or app-based visual timers to clearly delineate work periods, breaks, or transitions.
Instructions: Use a sand timer, a Time Timer (shows time depleting visually), or a large digital timer to help internalize time and prepare for changes in activity.
Unnamed: 5: time management, transitions, time perception, executive function, predictability, routine, visual aids

Description: Identifying or creating specific locations (even small ones) where you know you will not be overwhelmed by sensory input.
Instructions: This could be a specific chair in your home, a quiet park bench, or even just your car, where you can retreat when feeling overstimulated.
Unnamed: 5: sensory safe spaces, environmental accommodation, overwhelm, regulation, comfort, neurodiversity, autism

Description: Allowing yourself to switch tasks or change plans when energy or focus shifts, rather than forcing unproductive work.
Instructions: If a task isn't working or your brain isn't cooperating, give yourself permission to switch to something else or take a break, rather than pushing through unproductively.
Unnamed: 5: productivity, self-compassion, flexible thinking, task switching, energy management, burnout prevention

Description: Carrying a small, dedicated bag or pouch containing a variety of your most effective fidgets and sensory tools.
Instructions: Assemble a small, portable pouch with your go-to fidgets, chewing gum, a small stress ball, or other discreet sensory tools for use on the go.
Unnamed: 5: sensory regulation, fidgets, self-soothing, portability, discreet tools, anxiety management

Description: Using a familiar, low-demand TV show, podcast, or background noise to "fill" sensory space while performing boring or routine tasks.
Instructions: Play a comfort show you've seen many times, a podcast you enjoy, or white noise in the background while doing chores, cooking, or other tasks that don't require full auditory focus.
Unnamed: 5: focus, motivation, background stimulation, routine tasks, sensory regulation, ADHD

Description: Deliberately blocking out time in your schedule for unwinding and de-stressing after social events or demanding tasks.
Instructions: After a work meeting, social gathering, or a period of high focus, schedule 15-30 minutes of quiet, low-demand time for yourself to decompress.
Unnamed: 5: energy management, burnout prevention, decompression, self-care, social fatigue, stress reduction, autism, autistic burnout

Description: Talking through thoughts, problems, or plans out loud (to oneself, a pet, or a very patient person) to organize ideas.
Instructions: When feeling stuck or overwhelmed by thoughts, verbally articulate them out loud, as if explaining them to someone else, to help process and structure them.
Unnamed: 5: verbal processing, thought organization, problem-solving, cognitive load, externalization, clarity

Description: When overwhelmed, commit to doing only one tiny, manageable step towards a larger task.
Instructions: If a room needs cleaning, just pick up one item. If you need to send emails, just open the email client. The goal is just to start one thing.
Unnamed: 5: overwhelm reduction, task initiation, behavioral activation, procrastination, tiny steps, momentum, anxiety, grounding

Description: Mentally describing your sensory experience in detail as a way to ground yourself or process input.
Instructions: When feeling overwhelmed by a sensory input (e.g., a loud noise), mentally describe it to yourself: "That is a high-pitched, vibrating sound, coming from the fan on the left."
Unnamed: 5: self-soothing, mindfulness, sensory processing, grounding, overwhelm, regulation

Description: Setting multiple, sequential alarms to break down a larger task or transition into smaller, manageable steps.
Instructions: For a complex morning routine, set alarms for "wake up," "get out of bed," "get dressed," "eat breakfast," etc., to prompt each step.

Description: Re-watching or re-listening to familiar, predictable media that requires low cognitive load and provides comfort.
Instructions: Have a go-to list of comfort shows, movies, or albums you've seen/heard many times. Use them for background, de-stressing, or when overstimulated.

Description: Using large, highly visible boards (whiteboards, corkboards) to display tasks, schedules, or long-term goals.
Instructions: Write or stick tasks/goals on a prominent board where you can see them easily, making them tangible and harder to forget. Use different colors for categories.

Description: Identifying and noting down the specific times of day or conditions under which you are most productive or focused for different types of tasks.
Instructions: Keep a log: "When am I best at creative writing? (late night). When am I best at admin? (morning)." Schedule tasks accordingly.

Description: Engaging in activities that provide specific enjoyable sensory input, often reminiscent of childhood play.
Instructions: Examples: playing with kinetic sand, water beads, slime, building with LEGOs, or simply handling interesting textures.

Description: Creating intensely organized, designated spots for frequently lost or vital items.
Instructions: Have a specific, unchangeable "landing spot" for keys, wallet, phone, and glasses right inside the door or on your desk.

Description: Proactively blocking out empty, unstructured time in your schedule for rest and recovery, even if it feels unproductive.
Instructions: Treat "downtime" or "nothing time" as a scheduled appointment in your calendar that you cannot cancel.

Description: Consciously choosing what information to process or engage with, to prevent mental overwhelm.
Instructions: When faced with too much information (e.g., a noisy room, too many articles), deliberately narrow your focus to one piece of input at a time.

Description: Having certain clothing items or "uniforms" for specific activities to reduce decision fatigue and provide sensory predictability.
Instructions: Designate "work clothes," "relaxing clothes," "exercise clothes" that are comfortable and require no thought, reducing morning decision load.

Description: Ensuring short breaks are genuinely restful and not filled with other demanding activities.
Instructions: During a 5-minute break, avoid checking email or social media. Instead, look out a window, stretch, or grab water.

Description: Actively seeking or creating conditions that improve auditory comprehension (e.g., closed captions, asking for repetition).
Instructions: Use closed captions on all media. Don't hesitate to ask people to repeat themselves, speak slower, or rephrase when you're struggling to process.

Description: Having a go-to food or drink with specific sensory properties (e.g., temperature, flavor) that helps regulate or ground you.
Instructions: Keep items like cold, fizzy water; a specific sour candy; or a warm, comforting herbal tea on hand for immediate sensory input when feeling dysregulated.

Description: Linking a less preferred task to a highly preferred sensory input or interest.
Instructions: Only allow yourself to listen to your favorite podcast while doing the dishes, or only watch your comfort show while folding laundry.

Description: A simple visual grounding exercise to bring focus to the present moment, especially when feeling anxious or overwhelmed.
Instructions: Name 5 things you can see, then 4 things of a specific color, then 3 things with a certain shape, continuing to narrow your focus.

Description: Mentally rehearsing or having pre-written phrases for common social scenarios to reduce anxiety and communication difficulty.
Instructions: Before a phone call or meeting, think of common questions and practice brief, clear answers. Have an "escape phrase" ready for difficult conversations.

Description: Using a visual representation (e.g., a bar graph, pie chart) to plan and track your limited daily energy expenditure.
Instructions: Draw a daily "energy pie chart" or "battery bar" and allocate percentages to different activities to visualize where your energy is going.

Description: Seeking or performing firm, sustained pressure (e.g., a tight hug, squeezing yourself) for calming sensory input.
Instructions: If comfortable, ask a trusted person for a firm, sustained hug, or wrap your arms tightly around yourself and squeeze when feeling overwhelmed.

Description: A specific type of brain dump where you write down every single idea related to a project, no matter how small or chaotic.
Instructions: For a new project, dedicate 10-15 minutes to writing down every thought, task, idea, concern, or step that comes to mind, without censoring.

Description: Using specific types of music or noise to create a personal auditory "bubble" that blocks out distractions.
Instructions: Create playlists for different moods or tasks. Use classical music, instrumental scores, or specific genres that help you focus or relax without being distracting.

Description: Having a pre-planned set of very simple, immediate actions to break through task paralysis.
Instructions: When stuck, try: 1. "The 1-minute rule." 2. "Body doubling." 3. "Play one song and then try." 4. "Just open the document."

Description: A commitment to doing at least one small, productive thing each day, no matter how minor, to build momentum and combat stagnation.
Instructions: Even if you're feeling overwhelmed, aim to do one tiny task (e.g., send one email, wash one dish, spend 5 minutes on a project) to keep moving forward.

Description: Replacing a disruptive or uncomfortable sensory input with a more tolerable or preferred one.
Instructions: If a scratchy tag is bothering you, change your shirt. If loud noises are overwhelming, put on noise-canceling headphones or play calming music.

Description: Minimizing the number of times you switch between different tasks or mental contexts in a short period.
Instructions: Dedicate blocks of time to similar tasks (e.g., all emails at once, then all creative work) to avoid the mental cost of constantly refocusing.

Self_Regulation_Technique_Name: The 'Done Is Better Than Perfect' Mantra
Description: Reminding yourself that completing a task adequately is often more valuable than striving for unattainable perfection.
Instructions: When perfectionism leads to procrastination, repeat "Done is better than perfect" to encourage completion over endless refinement.

Description: Using visual aids to show how much of a task is left, helping to maintain motivation for longer activities.
Instructions: For long tasks (e.g., studying), draw a progress bar or divide the work into visual segments to see your progress as you go.

Description: A technique to interrupt repetitive, unhelpful thought loops by consciously acknowledging and then releasing them.
Instructions: When a thought loop starts, acknowledge it ("There's that thought again"). Then, visualize it floating away like a cloud or a leaf on a stream.

Description: Incorporating a personally comforting object into daily routines or challenging situations.
Instructions: Bring a favorite soft scarf to meetings, keep a familiar mug at your desk, or carry a small, smooth stone in your pocket for tactile comfort.

Description: Asking "why" repeatedly after a meltdown or shutdown to trace back and identify the underlying triggers.
Instructions: After recovering, reflect: "Why did I get overwhelmed? (e.g., too much noise). Why was the noise too much? (e.g., already tired)." Keep going until you hit a core cause.

Description: Having easy-to-grab, acceptable snacks or simple meals ready to reduce decision fatigue and ensure consistent fueling.
Instructions: Prep grab-and-go snacks, make large batches of simple meals, or keep a stash of preferred frozen meals for low-energy days.

Description: Curating specific auditory environments to suit different tasks or moods, beyond just noise masking.
Instructions: Create playlists or use apps with sounds specifically for focus (e.g., library sounds), relaxation (e.g., gentle rain), or energy (e.g., upbeat instrumental).

Description: Instead of just a to-do list, keeping a list of everything you have accomplished to boost morale and acknowledge effort.
Instructions: At the end of the day, or when feeling unaccomplished, write down all the tasks, big or small, that you actually completed.

Description: Using the physical placement of objects as a direct reminder or trigger for a task.
Instructions: Put your medications next to the kettle if you take them with morning tea, or leave your gym bag by the door to prompt your workout.

Description: Actively engaging in movements that provide desired sensory input, helping to regulate energy or focus.
Instructions: If under-stimulated, try bouncing on a yoga ball, swinging in a hammock, or doing a few spins or jumps (if safe and appropriate).

Description: Committing to a strict end time for work or demanding activities to prevent overextension and ensure rest.
Instructions: Set a non-negotiable end time for your workday or a challenging task, and stick to it, even if things aren't "perfectly" finished.

Description: Having a predefined strategy for how and when you will recharge after social interactions.
Instructions: After a social event, know if you need immediate quiet time, a comforting routine, or sensory input (e.g., a warm bath, noise-canceling headphones).

Description: Making small, repetitive decisions in advance (e.g., planning outfits for the week) to reduce daily mental load.
Instructions: On a Sunday, plan and perhaps even lay out your outfits for the entire week to eliminate daily decision fatigue.

Description: Using the shower or bath as a dedicated space for sensory regulation and intense calming.
Instructions: Focus on the sensory experience: the warmth of the water, the scent of soap, the sound of the spray. Use it as a mini-reset.

Description: Deliberately choosing specific colors or lighting in your environment that are visually calming or stimulating as needed.
Instructions: Use warm, soft lighting in your relaxation spaces. Opt for cooler, brighter lights in work areas if that aids focus. Incorporate colors you find visually soothing.

Description: Creating specific contingency plans for common challenges or potential pitfalls in your day or tasks.
Instructions: IF I get distracted by my phone, THEN I will put it in the other room. "IF I forget my keys, THEN I will check my 'key hook' immediately."

Description: Deliberately scheduling time to immerse yourself fully in a special interest as a powerful form of self-regulation and joy.
Instructions: Block out dedicated, uninterrupted time in your schedule to engage deeply with a special interest, allowing for intense focus and positive emotional recharge.

Description: Adjusting personal standards for cleanliness or organization to a realistic, sustainable level, rather than striving for perfection.
Instructions: Instead of aiming for sparkling clean, focus on "tidy enough to function." Prioritize safety and basic hygiene over immaculate perfection.

Description: Using specific tools or strategies to actively filter out unwanted sensory input from your environment.
Instructions: Wear sunglasses indoors if bright lights bother you, use earplugs or noise-canceling earbuds in noisy places, or wear a hat to reduce visual stimulation.

Description: Partnering with someone for mutual support on tasks, where the consequence for not doing it is simply checking in, not failure.
Instructions: Find a friend to simply check in with daily about your goals. The goal isn't punishment for not completing, but gentle encouragement and shared effort.

Description: Moving tasks to a different time, place, or method when the original approach isn't working, without guilt.
Instructions: If you can't focus on writing at your desk, try dictating into your phone while walking, or move to a coffee shop if that helps your focus.

Description: Engaging with familiar, low-stress books, audiobooks, or podcasts purely for comfort and relaxation, not for learning or productivity.
Instructions: Re-read a favorite book, listen to a familiar audiobook you know by heart, or put on a podcast that is soothing rather than stimulating.

Description: Adding extra, unplanned time between scheduled activities to allow for unexpected delays or necessary decompression.
Instructions: If one meeting ends at 11:00 AM and the next starts at 11:30 AM, mentally schedule the second at 11:45 AM to give yourself a buffer.

Description: Using physical objects or visual reminders to compensate for challenges with object permanence (out of sight, out of mind).
Instructions: Leave frequently used items (e.g., wallet, keys) in visible, designated spots rather than tucked away in drawers. Use clear containers for storage.

Description: Having a pre-determined exit strategy for social situations when you anticipate or experience overwhelm.
Instructions: Before a party, decide you'll stay for a specific amount of time, or identify a quiet spot you can retreat to, or have an excuse ready to leave.

Description: Identifying and regularly wearing a specific outfit or type of clothing that provides consistent, comfortable sensory input.
Instructions: Have one or more "go-to" outfits that always feel right (e.g., specific fabric, loose fit, no tags) to reduce daily sensory overwhelm from clothing.

Description: Deliberately blocking out time for activities that often trigger hyperfocus, turning it into a productive asset.
Instructions: If you know you can hyperfocus on coding or a creative project, schedule dedicated, uninterrupted blocks for it, rather than trying to force other tasks during that time.

Description: Stocking up on and relying heavily on meals that require minimal cooking, dishes, or mental effort.
Instructions: Keep a supply of microwaveable meals, pre-cut vegetables, or ingredients for very simple one-pan dishes for days when executive function is low.

Description: Wearing specialized clothing that provides consistent, gentle pressure across the torso for calming and grounding.
Instructions: Explore sensory compression vests or fitted athletic wear that offers comforting deep pressure, often worn discreetly under regular clothes.

Description: Using a special interest as a primary, intentional method for de-stressing and emotional regulation after a difficult day.
Instructions: Immediately after a stressful event, dedicate time to engaging deeply with your special interest (e.g., researching a topic, working on a collection, deep-diving into a game).

Description: Physically removing yourself from an overwhelming situation to prevent escalation of sensory overload or emotional dysregulation.
Instructions: If a place becomes too noisy or a conversation too intense, physically leave the area for a few minutes to regain composure.

Description: A variation of body scan focusing specifically on identifying and understanding different sensory inputs throughout the body.
Instructions: Lie down and systematically bring awareness to each part of your body, noticing not just tension, but how different textures, temperatures, or pressure feel.

Self_Regulation_Technique_Name: The 'One Item at a Time' Cleanup
Description: When a space is overwhelming, commit to only putting away or dealing with one single item at a time.
Instructions: Instead of looking at a messy room, just pick up one piece of trash, or put one item back in its place, then repeat.

Description: Using a calendar with pictures or simplified visual representations for daily activities and routines.
Instructions: Create a daily or weekly schedule using drawings, symbols, or photos for each activity, especially helpful for managing transitions.

Description: Grouping tasks by physical location to reduce context switching and unnecessary movement.
Instructions: Instead of doing one kitchen chore, then a bedroom chore, then back to the kitchen, tackle all kitchen chores at once before moving to another room.

Description: Creating a small, dedicated spot within your home with specific tools for quick sensory recalibration.
Instructions: This might include a comfortable pillow, a favorite fidget toy, a small bottle of a calming essential oil, and a pair of earplugs.

Description: A more structured brain dump where ideas are quickly categorized or bulleted as they come out, for easier processing later.
Instructions: Use a notebook with pre-drawn sections (e.g., "To Do," "Thoughts," "Ideas," "Worries") to quickly sort information as you dump it from your mind.

Description: Using a weighted eye mask to provide gentle pressure on the eyes, aiding in relaxation, reducing light sensitivity, and promoting sleep.
Instructions: Place a weighted eye mask over your eyes when resting, meditating, or trying to fall asleep to experience calming deep pressure.

Description: Pairing a highly disliked or difficult task with a genuinely enjoyable or stimulating activity.
Instructions: Only allow yourself to listen to your favorite podcast while doing the dishes, or only watch a specific show while folding laundry.

Description: Anticipating potential difficulties or triggers in advance and creating a plan to address them before they occur.
Instructions: Before a new social event, mentally rehearse possible scenarios and how you'll respond, or identify potential sensory triggers and how you'll mitigate them.

Description: Briefly mentally transporting yourself to a pleasant, imaginary place to de-stress and clear your mind.
Instructions: Close your eyes for 1-2 minutes and vividly imagine yourself in a favorite peaceful place (e.g., a quiet beach, a cozy cabin).

Description: Using specific temperatures or textures of drinks for regulation (e.g., very cold water, warm tea, fizzy drinks).
Instructions: Keep ice-cold water readily available for alertness, or a comforting warm beverage for relaxation, depending on your sensory need.

Description: Setting alarms on your phone with specific, descriptive labels or images to prompt tasks, not just times.
Instructions: Set an alarm that says "Pack Lunch" or "Take Meds" rather than just a time, to provide immediate context for the action.

Description: Focusing on tidying only one very small, specific area at a time (e.g., one shelf, one drawer) when feeling overwhelmed by mess.
Instructions: Instead of "clean the room," choose "clear off this one corner of the desk" or "organize this one section of the bookshelf."

Description: Having pre-prepared, low-energy ways to engage socially without extensive conversation or masking.
Instructions: For group gatherings, identify easy conversation topics (e.g., the food, a recent movie). Have simple questions ready ("How's your week been?").

Description: Deliberately seeking out specific sensory inputs in your immediate environment to ground yourself.
Instructions: When feeling overwhelmed, actively look for "something red," "something soft," "something that smells good," etc., to bring your focus to the present.

Description: Adjusting existing routines to better fit your natural energy fluctuations and preferences, rather than forcing a rigid schedule.
Instructions: If you're a night owl, shift non-essential morning tasks to the evening. If you dread a specific step, find a way to make it more palatable or delegate.

Description: Using apps, planners, or systems that are designed around your specific interests or aesthetics to make productivity more engaging.
Instructions: Find a task management app with a theme you love, or a physical planner with designs that genuinely excite you, to increase engagement.

Description: Making it a routine to utilize noise-canceling technology in environments that are typically overwhelming.
Instructions: Get into the habit of putting on noise-canceling headphones (even without music) when entering a busy office, public transport, or a noisy cafe.

Description: Consciously protecting yourself from absorbing others' strong negative emotions.
Instructions: If someone is highly stressed or angry, create mental boundaries. Remind yourself their emotions are theirs, not yours, and limit exposure if possible.

Description: Having a small selection of highly comfortable, sensory-friendly outfits that require no thought for daily wear.
Instructions: Curate 2-3 comfortable outfits that always feel good and fit well, and rotate them throughout the week to eliminate clothing decision fatigue.

Description: Using your special interest as a reliable mental and emotional refuge during times of stress or overwhelm.
Instructions: When feeling burnt out or dysregulated, retreat into your special interest – watch documentaries, read articles, organize your collection, without external pressure.

Description: Breaking a repetitive task into tiny, self-contained loops with built-in mini-rewards to maintain focus.
Instructions: For laundry, the loop is: "Pick up one item, fold it, place it in pile, then take a deep breath." Repeat.

Description: Rapidly typing or voice-to-texting overwhelming thoughts, ideas, or to-dos into a digital document.
Instructions: Use a notes app, a blank document, or a voice recorder to quickly capture everything in your head, then save it for later review.

Description: Quickly assessing the sensory environment of a new place before fully entering to anticipate potential overwhelm.
Instructions: Before walking into a noisy restaurant or bright store, pause at the entrance to gauge the light, sound, and smell levels.

Description: Creating plans with built-in flexibility and having clear backup options for when things don't go as expected.
Instructions: Plan your day, but also have "Plan B" options for key tasks if your energy or focus shifts unexpectedly. "If I can't do X, I will do Y instead."

Description: Developing internal scripts or strategies to manage intense emotional reactions to perceived criticism or rejection.
Instructions: When you feel the sting of perceived rejection, remind yourself: "This is my rejection sensitivity acting up. What is the objective reality? Is this really a personal attack, or something else?"

Description: Having a variety of fidget or stim toys and rotating them regularly to maintain novelty and effectiveness.
Instructions: Keep a few different types of stim toys. Rotate which ones you use daily or weekly to keep them interesting and to match different sensory needs.

Description: Writing down all outstanding thoughts, worries, or to-dos before bed to clear the mind and aid sleep.
Instructions: Before trying to sleep, take 5-10 minutes to write down everything on your mind, clearing your mental slate for rest.

Description: Acknowledging and celebrating even the smallest completed tasks to build momentum and positive reinforcement.
Instructions: After finishing a dreaded chore or a tiny step of a big project, take a moment to internally or externally acknowledge your achievement ("Yay, I did it!").

Description: Using specific food textures (e.g., crunchy, chewy, smooth) as a way to self-regulate and manage oral sensory needs.
Instructions: Keep a stash of preferred textured foods like crunchy carrots, chewy dried fruit, or smooth purees for sensory input.

Description: A simple rule for preventing clutter accumulation: when a new item comes in, one old, similar item must go out.
Instructions: When you buy a new shirt, donate or discard an old one. When you get a new book, give one away.

Description: Deliberately blocking out time for deep dives into special interests or highly engaging topics, as a reward or focus method.
Instructions: Instead of fighting a "rabbit hole" urge, schedule a specific time for it. "After I finish X, I can research Y for 30 minutes."

Description: Using a mental (or even physical) battery metaphor to track and communicate social energy levels.
Instructions: Mentally check your "social battery" throughout the day. If it's low, communicate to others, "My battery is running low," to set boundaries.

Description: Incorporating specific, often subtle, movements to aid concentration and manage restlessness.
Instructions: While working, try bouncing your leg, gently rocking, or pacing during phone calls if it helps you focus without disrupting others.

Description: Systematically assessing different rooms or environments for their sensory impact and identifying areas for modification.
Instructions: Walk through your home or office: "Is this light too harsh? Is that hum distracting? Where is my calmest spot?"

Description: Having short, prepared notes or scripts for anticipated challenging phone calls or interactions.
Instructions: Before making a customer service call or a difficult personal call, jot down key points, questions, and desired outcomes to stay on track.

Description: Creating a specific music playlist to help signal and facilitate transitions between different activities or moods.
Instructions: Have a "wake up" playlist, a "work focus" playlist, a "wind down" playlist, or a "pump-up" playlist for specific transitions.

Description: Designating specific areas or situations as visually "off-limits" when sensory overload is a risk.
Instructions: Avoid looking directly into bright lights. Use a screen filter. If a cluttered area triggers overwhelm, physically turn away or put up a visual barrier.

Description: Leaning into periods of intense, obsessive focus on a topic as a powerful learning or problem-solving method.
Instructions: When you feel a hyper-fixation starting on a relevant topic, allow yourself to dive deep, collecting information and making connections quickly.

Description: Having one designated, often messy, drawer or box for miscellaneous items that don't have a clear home.
Instructions: Instead of scattering small items, create one specific "everything drawer" where things go when you don't have the energy to put them away properly.

Description: Choosing personal care products based on their specific sensory qualities (scent, texture, temperature).
Instructions: Use a body wash with a scent you love, a toothpaste with a non-overwhelming flavor, or a hairbrush with bristles that feel good on your scalp.

Description: Framing tasks as acts of kindness or support for your future self, making them less daunting.
Instructions: Future me will be so grateful if current me just loads the dishwasher now. "I'm setting up future me for success by doing this task."

Description: Actively looking for recurring patterns or preceding events that lead to specific emotional states or overwhelm.
Instructions: Keep a simple log: "What happened just before I felt overwhelmed? What was I doing/experiencing before I got frustrated?"

Description: Suggesting or organizing social gatherings in environments known to be less sensually overwhelming.
Instructions: Suggest meeting at a quiet cafe during off-peak hours, going for a walk, or having a virtual chat instead of a loud restaurant or bar.

Description: Incorporating very small, discreet movements into static situations to help maintain focus or release restlessness.
Instructions: Wiggle your toes inside your shoes, gently rock in your chair, or tap your fingers subtly under the desk during meetings or lectures.

Description: Committing to only 5 minutes of a dreaded task, with the full permission to stop when the time is up.
Instructions: Set a timer for 5 minutes and tell yourself, "I only have to do this for 5 minutes." Often, once started, you'll continue beyond 5 minutes.

Description: A deliberate sequence of actions to systematically reduce sensory input after a stimulating environment.
Instructions: After a busy day, dim lights, put on noise-canceling headphones, change into comfort clothes, and engage in a calming sensory activity.

Description: Structuring your day or week around periods of high interest or motivation, rather than strict time blocks.
Instructions: Identify when you feel naturally drawn to certain tasks (e.g., coding late at night, creative work in the morning) and schedule them then.

Description: Using physical or digital visual cues to mark off completed tasks, providing a satisfying sense of accomplishment.
Instructions: Use a whiteboard, a large planner, or a digital checklist app where you can physically tick, cross out, or move tasks to a "done" column.

Description: Keeping a reliable supply of a few specific foods that are always palatable and sensory-safe, especially for low-energy days.
Instructions: Stock your pantry with a few go-to "safe foods" that you know you can always eat, even when overstimulated or executive function is low.

Description: Curating a music playlist specifically designed to aid focus, calm, or energize without being distracting.
Instructions: Create playlists with instrumental music, specific genres (e.g., lo-fi, classical), or natural sounds that help you concentrate or relax without demanding attention.

Description: Scheduling dedicated time to freely write or speak all thoughts and information swirling in your mind, for release and organization.
Instructions: Set a timer for 10-15 minutes and just dump all thoughts, ideas, and worries onto paper or into a voice recording, without judgment or pressure to act.

Description: Utilizing online platforms or apps that connect you with others working in parallel for shared focus and accountability.
Instructions: Join a virtual "body doubling" session or use an app that provides a quiet, shared virtual workspace to help stay on task.

Description: Rehearsing simple, clear ways to say "no" or set limits without over-explaining or feeling guilty.
Instructions: Practice phrases like "That doesn't work for me," "I have a prior commitment," or "I need to prioritize my energy right now" in front of a mirror.

Description: Using specific essential oils or other scents known to promote calmness and reduce anxiety.
Instructions: Keep a rollerball with lavender oil, a calming room spray, or a scented candle nearby to use when feeling overwhelmed or needing to relax.

Description: Integrating very short bursts of special interest engagement into work or study periods as quick motivators.
Instructions: After completing a small task, allow yourself 1-2 minutes to look at a favorite image related to your special interest, read a fun fact, or watch a short clip.

Description: Using a large whiteboard to visually map out thoughts, tasks, or project components, leveraging visual processing.
Instructions: Dedicate a section of a whiteboard to "ideas," "to-do," "currently working on," and move things around as you process them.

Description: Assembling a small bag with essential sensory regulation tools to take with you when leaving the house.
Instructions: Pack earplugs/headphones, a favorite fidget, a calming scent, and perhaps a small, comforting snack or drink for public outings.

Description: Deliberately blocking out time in your day or week where you consciously allow yourself to drop any social masking.
Instructions: Schedule specific periods (e.g., an hour after work, Saturday mornings) where you can be fully yourself, without performing or conforming.

Description: Creating lists or reminders specifically for your future self, as if you're helping a different person.
Instructions: Write a note: "Hey future me, remember to pack your lunch for tomorrow!" or "Future me will thank current me for tidying this up now."

Description: Keeping specific items with satisfying textures readily available for tactile self-soothing.
Instructions: Have a smooth stone, a velvet cloth, a squishy stress ball, or a plush toy that you can touch and manipulate for comfort.

Description: When completely stuck, commit to just starting the absolute first step of a task, even if it's just opening a document.
Instructions: Don't aim to complete the task; just aim to initiate it. Opening the document, turning on the computer, or getting the cleaning supplies out counts.

Description: Paying attention to your own physical sensations and body language as early warning signs of stress or overwhelm.
Instructions: Notice tension in your shoulders, fidgeting, or shallow breathing. Use these physical cues as a signal to engage a self-regulation hack.

Description: Using large, clear visual timers (like kitchen timers or apps with big numbers) to manage time blindness and transitions.
Instructions: Place a large timer in a visible spot. Set it for specific work blocks, breaks, or to signal when it's time to switch tasks or leave.

Description: Creating an auditory environment that promotes calm through chosen sounds or minimal sound.
Instructions: Use noise-canceling headphones, play white/brown/pink noise, or listen to soft, consistent ambient sounds (e.g., gentle rain, distant ocean waves).

Description: Focusing only on what needs to be done today, letting go of the burden of future tasks or past failures.
Instructions: When feeling overwhelmed by a large workload or long-term goals, tell yourself, "I only need to focus on what's actionable just for today."

Description: Using a weighted plush toy or stuffed animal for comforting deep pressure input and emotional support.
Instructions: Keep a weighted stuffed animal nearby to hold, place on your lap, or cuddle with when feeling anxious, overwhelmed, or needing comfort.

Description: Modifying lighting to reduce harshness or overstimulation, using warm tones or indirect light.
Instructions: Use dimmers, warm-toned light bulbs (e.g., smart bulbs that change color), lamps instead of overhead lights, or string lights for softer illumination.

Description: Creating a specific, ritualistic action to signal the end of the workday or a demanding task, promoting mental disengagement.
Instructions: At the end of work, close a specific application, put away a certain item, or say "Done for the day!" out loud to transition out of work mode.

Description: Creating clear, simple visual charts for rules or expectations in shared spaces to reduce ambiguity.
Instructions: In a shared home, create a chart for "kitchen rules" or "laundry steps" with simple text or pictures to minimize misunderstandings and friction.

Description: A dedicated section in a planner or notebook specifically for tracking and managing current hyper-fixations.
Instructions: Jot down notes, links, or ideas related to your current hyper-fixation here. This acknowledges it without letting it derail other tasks.

Description: Using specific sounds or songs as a non-verbal signal for upcoming transitions or routine steps.
Instructions: Play a particular song to signal the start of your morning routine, or a chime to indicate it's time to switch tasks.

Description: A playlist specifically curated with songs that reliably evoke feelings of calm, joy, or catharsis.
Instructions: Create a playlist of songs that consistently help you regulate your emotions, whether for calming down, feeling motivated, or processing sadness.

Description: Having pre-assembled bags for common outings (e.g., gym, library, park) to reduce decision fatigue and forgotten items.
Instructions: Keep a gym bag packed, a "library run" bag with books and cards, or a "park bag" with water and sunscreen, ready to grab and go.

Description: Utilizing a simple, consistent, and visually calm background for video calls or digital workspaces.
Instructions: Choose a plain wall, a simple curtain, or a consistent virtual background to minimize visual distractions for yourself and others during calls.

Description: Very short meditative practices that focus intensely on one specific sense to ground yourself quickly.
Instructions: For 30-60 seconds, focus only on the sensation of your breath, the feeling of your feet on the floor, or one specific sound in the room.

Description: Using a voice recording of yourself or a text-to-speech app to externalize instructions for a task.
Instructions: If reading instructions is hard, record yourself saying the steps of a task, or use text-to-speech to read them aloud, making them easier to process.

Description: Carrying small, discreet comfort objects that provide tactile or other sensory input without drawing attention.
Instructions: Keep a smooth stone, a worry coin, a small piece of textured fabric, or a small, silent fidget in your pocket for discreet self-soothing.

Description: Having specific individuals or groups with whom you have a mutual understanding of low-pressure, asynchronous communication.
Instructions: Establish with certain friends that it's okay for messages to go unanswered for days, and that calls don't require immediate answers, reducing social pressure.

Description: Placing highly visible reminders for essential self-care tasks (e.g., hydrate, stretch, eat) around your environment.
Instructions: Put sticky notes on your monitor to drink water, a reminder on your bathroom mirror to stretch, or a fruit bowl in plain sight to prompt healthy eating.

Description: A mental or physical "card" you give yourself permission to use when you need to completely reset your day or current state.
Instructions: When a day goes completely off the rails, mentally (or literally) declare, "I'm using my reset card." Then, pivot to a self-soothing or low-demand activity.

Description: Using specific sounds or auditory information to feel safe or aware of your surroundings.
Instructions: Playing specific background music at home to feel less isolated, or using headphones with a "transparency" mode in public to stay aware of surroundings.

Description: Establishing a pre-arranged plan with a trusted person for what to do during or after a meltdown/shutdown.
Instructions: Agree with a trusted friend/partner on specific actions (e.g., quiet space, bring water, no talking) if you're experiencing sensory overload or emotional distress.

Description: Mentally walking through every step of a task in vivid detail before starting, to aid planning and reduce overwhelm.
Instructions: Before doing laundry, visualize each step: carrying the basket, sorting, loading, starting machine, moving to dryer, folding, putting away.

Description: A small container filled with various sensory "snacks" (small items that provide quick, diverse sensory input).
Instructions: Fill a small box with items like a mini stress ball, a strong-smelling essential oil wipe, a piece of crunchy gum, or a smooth stone for quick sensory input.

Description: Mentally or physically preparing answers to common social questions (e.g., "How are you?") to reduce social anxiety.
Instructions: Before a social event, think about predictable questions and have a few generic, comfortable answers ready, so you don't have to formulate them on the spot.

Description: Using a weighted vest or a heavy scarf/shawl to provide constant, comforting deep pressure.
Instructions: Wear a weighted vest designed for sensory input, or simply drape a heavy scarf or shawl around your shoulders/lap when needing grounding pressure.

Description: Breaking large tasks into segments that match your fluctuating energy levels throughout the day or week.
Instructions: Instead of "write report," split it into "outline (high focus)," "research (medium focus)," "draft paragraphs (low focus)," and tackle them when your energy aligns.

Description: Using the deliberate sensory experience of a shower or bath as a complete reset for overwhelm or dysregulation.
Instructions: Focus intensely on the sensory input: the water temperature, the sound, the steam, the scent of soap. Treat it as a mindful reset button.

Description: Using analog clocks, sand timers, or visual countdown timers to make time more concrete and manageable.
Instructions: Use a large, visible analog clock, a sand timer for short tasks, or a Time Timer (shows time visually disappearing) to help with time blindness.

Description: Pre-selecting or preparing outfits based purely on their comfortable and preferred sensory textures.
Instructions: Before laundry day, identify your absolute favorite-feeling clothes. Wash them together and prioritize wearing them when you need sensory comfort.

Description: A small, portable kit of easy-to-eat, non-perishable "safe foods" for unexpected low-energy or overwhelm moments.
Instructions: Keep a small bag with granola bars, nuts, or individually wrapped sensory-preferred candies in your backpack, car, or desk drawer.

Description: Deliberately blocking out time in your schedule where there is no expectation to be productive or social.
Instructions: Treat "do nothing" time as a vital appointment. Lie down, stare at the ceiling, or sit quietly without phone, book, or task.

Description: A gentle decluttering method: whenever you leave a room, take one item that doesn't belong and put it away.
Instructions: As you exit a room, scan for one item out of place (e.g., a mug, a book) and take it with you to put away.

Description: Designing self-care routines around activities that provide specific, regulating sensory input.
Instructions: Instead of just "relax," choose specific sensory self-care: a hot bath with epsom salts, listening to calming music with headphones, or using a vibrating massage tool.

Description: A brief mental or physical checklist to prepare for social interactions, reducing anxiety and improving performance.
Instructions: Before a social event, quickly review: "Do I know the topic? Do I have an exit plan? Am I wearing comfortable clothes? Do I have my fidget?"

Description: Setting alarms or reminders to break out of a hyperfocus period to avoid losing track of time or other commitments.
Instructions: If you know you're prone to hyperfocus, set an alarm that says "Time to switch tasks!" or "Check in on X!" every 30-60 minutes.

Description: Pairing a positive affirmation with a physical touch or action to create a rapid self-soothing response.
Instructions: Choose an affirmation ("I am safe," "I am capable"). Repeat it while pressing your thumb and forefinger together. Use the touch later to recall the feeling.

Description: A simple visual representation (mental or drawn) of your energy level throughout the day to guide activity choices.
Instructions: Mentally picture your "energy bar" (like in a video game). If it's low, prioritize rest. If high, tackle more demanding tasks.

Description: A container filled with various items that offer diverse, satisfying sensory experiences for hands-on calming.
Instructions: Create a bin with kinetic sand, water beads, smooth stones, dried beans, or small fidget toys to run your hands through for tactile input.

Description: Limiting your daily "must-do" tasks to the three most crucial items to prevent overwhelm and ensure essential progress.
Instructions: At the start of each day, identify only the three absolute most important things you need to achieve, and focus on those first.

Description: Giving yourself instructions out loud for tasks, as if teaching someone else, to aid processing and initiation.
Instructions: Okay, first I need to open the document. Then I'll find the section for X. Then I'll start typing.

Description: Surrounding yourself with elements related to your special interests to create a more engaging and motivating space.
Instructions: Decorate your workspace with items related to your special interest, or have books/models related to it visible to subtly boost mood and focus.

Description: Deliberately blocking out short periods for unrestricted, sensory-seeking movement.
Instructions: If you have trouble sitting still, schedule 5-10 minutes every hour or two to walk, stretch, dance, or engage in other preferred movements.

Description: Developing specific, kind phrases to use when you're being self-critical or experiencing intense emotional distress.
Instructions: When feeling down, tell yourself, "It's okay to feel this way," or "I'm doing my best, and that's enough," as if speaking to a loved one.

Self_Regulation_Technique_Name: The 'Out of Sight, Out of Mind' Solution
Description: Strategically putting away distracting items or visual clutter that can lead to overwhelm.
Instructions: Use opaque bins, close cupboard doors, or put distracting items in a separate room when you need to focus or feel overwhelmed by visual chaos.
